===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|わ}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=わ}} {{m|zh|和|tr=hwa||harmonious}}.

The “Japan” sense appears during the reign of [[w:Empress Genmei|Empress Genmei]] (707–715), as this character {{lang|ja|和}} was chosen as a homophone with a more favorable meaning to replace the previous character {{m|ja|倭|tr=wa}} then in use as the kanji name for Japan<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> (see the etymology at {{ja-r|大和|^やまと}} for more details). The “Japan” sense was usually read with a [[訓読み#Japanese|kun'yomi]] of ''yamato'', until some time in the [[w:Muromachi period|Muromachi period]], when the [[漢音#Japanese|kan'on]] reading of ''Wa'' became more common.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|やまと}}
Appears during the reign of [[w:Empress Genmei|Empress Genmei]] (707–715), as this character {{lang|ja|和}} was chosen as a homophone with a more favorable meaning to replace the previous character {{m|ja|倭|tr=wa}} then in use as the kanji name for Japan<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> (see the etymology at {{ja-r|大和|^やまと}} for more details). The “Japan” sense was usually read with a [[訓読み#Japanese|kun'yomi]] of ''Yamato'', until some time in the [[w:Muromachi period|Muromachi period]], when the [[漢音#Japanese|kan'on]] reading of ''Wa'' became more common.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

In modern Japanese, the ''Yamato'' reading is more commonly spelled {{ja-l|大和}}.
